homescreen.dshomesec1_content_descriptions: Features and services provided in the PayPay app are designed according to this style guide.

dshomesec2_content_descriptions.descriptions: The style of the PayPay app is defined here.
All products provided by PayPay are designed based on this style guide.
Keeping the design in line with a consistent set of rules fosters the PayPay Brand and raises the user’s awareness of it.
Doing this also reduces the effort it takes for the user to lean the UIUX and enables the provision of a comfortable user experience.
There are two parts to the style guide. The Global Rules and Components.

homescreen.dshomesec3_content_descriptions: PayPay's Design Philosophy is the quintessence of PayPay’s designs, and is something that will not change. There are 4 keywords.

dshomesec3_content_philosophy.dshomesec3_philo_descriptions: We provide designs that are close to the user's life and sympathize with them.
Strip off the extra stuff so the user can focus only on what's important.
The UI components provided by the app comply with the components in this guideline.
We aim to make your daily life happy with PayPay, and provide fun, human-like, and warm designs.

dshomesec4_content_descriptions.descriptions: The Global Rule is an overarching concept in the PayPay app style guide.
Components are designed according to this concept.

dshomesec5_content_descriptions.descriptions: This is a guideline for the individual UI parts, designed based on the Global Rule.
All screens provided in the PayPay app are designed and implemented using the UI parts listed here.
Complying with the rules for the different parts ensures a consistent design quality in the UI, as well as providing a consistent UX.
It also contributes to the redundancy of design & development efforts.

color.title: Color
color.principle_desc_1: Colors are used to provide clarification on the priority of information and required actions. Using specific colors for particular actions or statuses helps to maintain consistency across services, reducing the effort it takes for the user to learn the UIUX.
color.principle_desc_2: The UI must use the colors defined by each component. Consistent use of colors fosters the character of the brand.
color.principle_desc_3: Readability and visibility must be ensured with all contents through a color scheme that enables anyone to view the contents comfortably.
color.definition_pattern_desc: There are three definitions of PayPay colors: the brand color, global colors and extended colors.
color.brand_color_desc_1: The brand color represents the PayPay brand itself and is used in the logo.
color.brand_color_desc_2: It is not recommended to use this color for elements other than the PayPay logo.
color.global_color_asset_desc_1: Global color assets represent PayPay itself.
color.global_color_asset_desc_2: It consists of a combination of four colors including the brand color or the gradation color.
color.global_color_asset_desc_3: The use of these colors facilitates the user’s recognition of the PayPay brand.
color.global_color_asset_desc_4: It is recommended to use a combination of the four solid colors to represent the PayPay brand in general, and to use the gradation color when representing the consumer app.
color.dont_desc_1: It is prohibited to use the global colors in a way that causes a color halation that makes the user uncomfortable.
color.dont_desc_2: It is prohibited to use colors in a way that makes the user feel uncomfortable.
color.ext_color_asset_desc_1: The extended color assets refer to a set of color assets that include the global colors.
color.ext_color_asset_desc_2: It is used for UI components, illustrations, icons, and as an added accent in certain contents.
color.ext_color_asset_desc_3: The color scheme must be fun, friendly and convey a sense of security, based on PayPay’s design philosophy of expressing “empathy” and “happiness”.
color.ext_color_asset_color_desc_1: The color palette consists of twelve chromatic hues in four levels, and eight achromatic colors in eight levels.
color.ext_color_asset_color_desc_2: It is recommended to use line 01 and 04 in the UI.
color.ext_color_asset_color_desc_3: It is recommended to add a background color to the contents when using colors from line 04.
color.ext_color_asset_color_desc_4: It is prohibited to use colors from line 04 for text and action parts.
color.ext_color_asset_color_desc_5: It is acceptable to use a given color for illustrations etc. when it is necessary to use a color that is not included in the color palette.
color.functional_color_desc_1: Functional color assets are color assets assigned with a particular function.
color.functional_color_desc_2: Maintaining consistency across color functions reduces the effort it takes for the user to learn the UIUX, providing a comfortable experience.
color.functional_color_desc_3: The colors are taken from the extended color assets.
color.functional_color_dont_desc: It is prohibited to use the colors in the following way as it may confuse the user about what action to take.
color.gradation_color_desc_1: A gradation consisting of the extended color assets may be used as the UI color of partner services and marketing tools.
color.gradation_color_desc_2: It is, however, prohibited to use the PayPay gradation defined as the global color for features other than PayPay’s main features.
color.gradation_color_desc_3: It is necessary to comply with the defined rules when using gradation colors.
color.accessibility_desc_1: When displaying text in primary contents, the contrast between the background color and foreground color must be at least 3:1.
color.accessibility_desc_2: This excludes supplementary components or when the text exists only for decorative purposes.
color.accessibility_desc_3: Also, there is no contrast requirement for text used in a logo or brand name.

dont_imgs.name: Use colors other than those defined as function colors.
Heavy use of the action color for non-action components.

grdtn_rule.name: Orientation
grdtn_rule.discription: 90°is the only angle allowed for the orientation of the gradation. Colors are specified only at points 0% (1) and 100% (2). It is fine to specify colors with different hues for (1) and (2). When specifying colors with different hues, similar hues are used. It is prohibited to select colors with hues that are too far apart.

grdtn_rule.name: Top
grdtn_rule.discription: A color with high brightness is specified at the top end (0%) of the gradation. It is recommended to use a hue defined in the color palette. It is recommended to use a brightness between 90-100.

grdtn_rule.name: Bottom
grdtn_rule.discription: A color with a lower brightness and chroma is specified at the bottom end (100%) of the gradation. It is recommended to use a brightness between 80-100.

gradations_imgs.name: Specify three or more colors in the gradation.
Specify a dark color on the top and a bright color on the bottom.
Specify a dark color on the top and a bright color on the bottom.
Use a combination of hues that are far apart.
It is prohibited to use the PayPay Gradation other than for PayPay’s main features, such as for an external service or mini app.

philosophy.philos_sect1_description1: PayPay's design philosophy is the basis of the PayPay app style guide and is something that will not change.
philosophy.philos_sect1_description2: The app UX that PayPay provides is designed based on this philosophy

descriptions.desc: Designs that are close to and empathetic to the user’s daily life are provided.
The service has to blend into everyday life like water or air and be easily accessible to everyone, whether young, old, man or woman.
A constant dialogue with the user is strived for, instead of pushing a service unilaterally.
Making the user’s life more convenient and enriched through their use of PayPay is strived for, listening to their voice no matter small it may be.
Ensuring that the user can feel safe and trust the service is of utmost importance.
Any surplus is removed so that the user can focus on what is important.
All hindrances for the user to achieve a goal are eliminated to ensure whatever the user has to get done can be completed in the shortest possible time.
All UIs are kept regular and consistent.
The effort required to learn is eliminated as much as possible so that the user can continue to use the service comfortably.
All UI components provided in the app follow the rules in this document.
Aiming for happiness in the user’s daily life through PayPay, a fun, down to earth, and warm design is provided.
Going beyond mere payments, going beyond being a convenient tool, a design that touches the user’s emotions is strived for.
Without being bound to the image of ‘payment’ or ‘financial service’, a fun, cheerful and exciting image should be conveyed.

illustration.title: Illustration

principle_desc.desc: Illustrations are used to facilitate a clear and intuitive understanding of the contents.
It is prohibited to use illustrations that are offensive or misleading.

title_usage_desc.desc: Illustrations are used in the most effective way possible.

txt_convey_desc.desc: By using an illustration, it is possible to communicate the subject matter of contents more deeply compared to when using just text.
In addition, an illustration can be used as a decorative element for a campaign etc., to appeal to the user’s emotions and create excitement.

txt_convey_desc_2.desc: The user’s understanding is facilitated by providing a visual explanation of a category.

illustration.txt_convey_desc_cnt_12: The illustration supplements what cannot be conveyed by text.
illustration.txt_expression_desc_1: In accordance with the Design Philosophy,
illustration.txt_expression_desc_2: expressions that embody the brand image of PayPay are used

txt_expression_desc.desc: Motifs used in illustrations are simplified as much as possible.
Only fill is used for coloring, using colors based on the color palette provided in Color.
Friendly expressions are used that are not overly inanimate.
Expressions representing a specific individual or business are not used

txt_dont_desc.desc: It is prohibited to use the following expressions at all times.。

usageIllustration.desc_2: The user’s understanding is facilitated by providing a visual explanation of a category.
While communicating that the user has won, the decorative design helps create excitement for the user.

donts.desc: Expressions that deviate from the guideline, such as line/watercolor drawings.
Expressions in breach of the company’s brand or third party’s brand. It is not allowed to change the shape or color of the PayPay logo and use it in an illustration.

illustration_design_sect3_images_tableho.name: panel1
illustration_design_sect3_images_tableho.illustration_design_sect3_images_colo2: A stronger color is used to highlight something or for the main theme. Conversely, a low tone color is used for supplementary elements. In this way, a contrast is created within the illustration to provide clarity on the main theme.

illustration_design_sect3_images_tableho.name: panel2
illustration_design_sect3_images_tableho.illustration_design_sect3_images_colo2: When using an illustration of a person, their facial expression is left blank in principle unless when necessary.

interaction.title: Interaction

principle_desc.desc: Touch screen devices such as smartphones and tablets in particular must provide an intuitive experience.
All action components need to be interactive.
The user needs to be able to visually understand what is happening, providing affordance for required actions, as well as providing clear feedback after the action.

title_usage_desc.desc: Gestures refer to the different behaviors the user can enact on a touch device.。
There are many different types of gestures. In principle, they follow the standard gestures defined by the device.
Some standard gestures do however have a complex behavior, in which case, support should be provided to prevent users from missing or mishandling them.

title_feedback_desc.desc: An action component always provides feedback after a user’s action.
Through the feedback, the user comes to know of whether the action was successful or not.

title_touch_feedback_table.name: iOS
title_touch_feedback_table.desc: A color with a brightness 5 lower than the normal color of the component is used to provide touch feedback. The color of the texts remains the same, but with 70% transparency. Refer to the individual components for the colors of the touch feedback.

title_touch_feedback_table.name: Android
title_touch_feedback_table.desc: Is in accordance with the ripple effect of the OS.

noticeofresults_desc.desc: In addition to feedback on the action, it is also recommended to provide feedback on the result after the user has performed the action.
By displaying the result, the user will come to know whether the action was successful or not.

interaction.txt_noticeofresults: Refer to the Toast section for more information on the components for displaying feedback.

tap_desc.desc: Tapping is the action of touching a component.
It is the most standard gesture.

txt_tap_desc.desc: For tap actions that do not utilize standard components such as a button、
it is mandatory to provide visual support to ensure the users understands it can be tapped.
It is mandatory to display supporting components to clearly indicate the current position within the entire contents.

interaction.txt_touch_guide: Display a visual element to indicate a tap.

scroll_desc.desc: Scrolling is the action of moving information upwards or downwards to enabling viewing it when there are multiple contents displayed in continuation and it does not fit into the screen.
The contents mirror the movement of the user’s finger.
If the user scrolls quickly, the device's standard inertial scrolling is activated for the information to be displayed efficiently.

interaction.txt_scroll_desc: When the user is required to view information-heavy contents, it is mandatory to display supporting components to provide clarity on what information is currently being displayed and at which position the users is amongst all the contents.

flick_desc.desc: Flicking is the action of lightly striking a component sideways with a finger.
When it is difficult to place a lot of information on the screen, components are horizontally lined-up outside of the screen and made viewable by flicking sideways.

interaction.txt_flick_desc: To indicate that it is possible to flick and display information, it is mandatory to display supporting components.
interaction.drag_slide_view_desc_1: Dragging is the action of pulling one part of the component to reveal a component previously hidden on the screen.
interaction.drag_slide_view_desc_2: To indicate that it is possible to display information by dragging, it is mandatory to display supporting components.

drag_drop_desc.desc: Drag & drop is the action of pulling and moving one part of the component with a finger and then letting it go.
It is used in cases such as when rearranging a list.

pinch_desc.desc: Pinching-out is the action of placing a thumb and finger on the screen and moving them apart to zoom in.
Pinching-in is the reverse action to zoom out.
It is used to shrink or enlarge maps or images.

txt_pinch_content.desc: Even if it is a standard gesture, if it is a gesture the user is unfamiliar with or is difficult to understand, its use is not recommended.
For gestures such as the long press, double tap, or other gestures requiring three fingers, it is mandatory to educate the user and display a supporting UI that functions as an affordance.

scroll_desc_img.desc: Display the title of the current display at the top of the screen.

flick_desc_img.desc: Display content hidden at the edge of the screen.

drag_slide_desc.desc: Components that encourage the drag gesture.

igrphy_sect1_description: The use of icons facilitates an intuitive understanding of the contents.
An icon must function even when on its own. It must be something that makes sense at a glance without using text
An icon should be free of unnecessary decorations, consisting of a simple and friendly design.

igrphy_sect1_images.name: pannel1
desc: Simple representations with no unnecessary decoration.

igrphy_sect1_images.name: pannel2
desc: It is prohibited to use 3D representations, hand-drawn designs, and organic shapes.

igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.name: no2
igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect2_images_colo2: Supplements the contents of a menu

igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.name: no3
igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect2_images_colo2: A single icon that represents a feature

igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.name: no4
igrphy_sect2_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect2_images_colo2: Supplements the contents in a half sheet

icongraphy.igrphy_sect3_subtitle: The colors used in an icon depend on the type of the icon.

igrphy_sect3_holders.name: panel1
igrphy_sect3pnel_descriptions: A service icon represents a PayPay feature or service.
In addition to the basic navy blue, a single color that has a likeness with the service is selected and applied.
Refer to Specs on selecting a color.

igrphy_sect3_holders.name: panel2
igrphy_sect3pnel_descriptions: A system icon refers to an icon used for an app feature or action.
A system icon may use just one color or two blues: navy blue and blue.

igrphy_sect3_holders.name: panel3
igrphy_sect3pnel_descriptions: A status is represented by combining a system icon with a status mark.
It is used for half-sheets and explaining an action.
A status mark must not be used if it impairs the visibility of the icon. Also, it must be big enough to ensure sufficient visibility.

igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel1
igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect3_images_colo2: Displayed when the action is completed and processed successfully.

igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel2
igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect3_images_colo2: Displayed when confirming or executing an additional action.

igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel3
igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect3_images_colo2: Displayed when confirming or executing an invalid action.

igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel4
igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect3_images_colo2: Displayed when confirming or executing a delete action.

igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel5
igrphy_sect3_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect3_images_colo2: Displayed in case of an error or alert

igrphy_sect4_images_tableholder.name: panel4
igrphy_sect4_images_colo2: Templates are available as Ai data. There are guides in the template data that match the shape. In the template data, guides are displayed along the contour. When creating an icon, refer the guides closest to the form of the icon being created.
Refer to Template for details on templates.

icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_description: Select a color from the color palette below.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_mccolordesc: Navy blue is used as the common main color.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_accolordesc: Accent colors are used to part of the motif. One of the four colors on the left that matches the service image is used.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_aysccolordesc1: Select a color from the color palette below.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_aysccolordesc2: A system icon consists of a combination of the two colors on the left or just one color.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect5_dont_des: It is prohibited to use unspecified colors.
igrphy_sect6_description: It is recommended to work-off a template (Ai) when creating an icon.
The template is made at twice the actual size.
Please reduce the size to 1/2 after completing the icon and using it in Sketch/Figma.

igrphy_sect6_images_tableholder.name: panel1
igrphy_sect6_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect4_images_colo2: The icon area is padded by a 2px margin. The main icon motif is not placed within the padding.

igrphy_sect6_images_tableholder.name: panel2
igrphy_sect6_images_tableholder.igrphy_sect4_images_colo2: The main icon motif is placed within the 20px*20px area on the inside of the padding area.

igrphy_sect7_description: In the template data, there are guides displayed in the form of different shapes.
When creating an icon, refer the guides closest to the form of the icon being created.
icongraphy.igrphy_sect9_description: The icon needs to be created at twice the actual size.。

layout_sect1_description: There are rules that define the placement of components and margins within a screen.
Regardless of platform or environment, creating designs that follow the defined rules ensure consistency across all environments.
layout.layout_sect2_description: As a general rule, px/dps that are multiples of four are used for margins within the screen.
layout.layout_sect2_hints: Exceptions are permitted for components comprising a complex combination of small parts.
layout_sect3_description: When creating common web contents displayed across smartphone web/app screens, tablet or desktop screens, a layout that does not impair usability regardless of the environment must be ensured.

Reaching the breakpoint defined below will trigger a switch between the smartphone / desktop layouts. Since tablets are considered as an extension of smartphones, there is only one breakpoint defined.
layout.layout_sect4_description: There two main types of margins.

layout_sect4_images_tableholder.name: panel1
layout_sect4_images_tableholder.desc: The margin between the edge of the screen and the contents

layout.layout_sect5_title: The margin between the edge of the screen and the contents
layout.layout_sect5_description: A margin is inserted between the edge of the screen and the contents to ensure visibility of the contents. In a smartphone environment, a 24px/16px margin is used. Below are examples on which margin to use.
layout.layout_sect5_hint1: Screens in which user input / action buttons are the primary contents
layout.layout_sect5_hint2: Screens in which card UIs and lists are the primary contents
layout.layout_sect6_description:
A 40px/24px margin is used for tablet or desktop environments.
Reaching the breakpoint will trigger the margins to switch.
layout.layout_sect7_description: A sufficient margin is ensured between contents when arranging them adjacently, providing clarity on information that are grouped together. It is recommended to use an 8px/12px/16px margin when multiple contents are displayed adjacently.
layout.layout_sect7_hint: The components placed between margins are defined using a percentage, not a fixed value. The margin is designated using a fixed value. The size of the component is variable according to the size of the device.
layout_sect8_description: It is prohibited to place action components outside the safe area for devices with notches or cutout areas.
It is recommended to display only visual elements outside the safe area.
Displaying a background color or other decorative elements outside the safe area helps to make the screen look spacious, providing a more comfortable experience.

layout_sect8_images_tableholder.name: panel1
layout_sect8_images_tableholder.col2:
For iOS devices, the safe area is 44px at the top of the screen and 34px at the bottom.
Refer to the iOS Human Interface Guideline for details

layout_sect8_images_tableholder.name: panel2
layout_sect8_images_tableholder.col2:
For Android devices, the size of the cutout area depends on the device model.
Refer to the Support Display Cutout for details.

layout.layout_sect8_hint: Placing action components inside the safe area

layout_sect8_icons_tableholder.name: panel1
layout_sect8_icons_tableholder.desc: Place action components inside the safe area.

layout_sect8_icons_tableholder.name: panel2
layout_sect8_icons_tableholder.desc: Place action components outside the safe area.

layout.layout_sect9_description:
There are several template layouts.
The different layouts are used according to the concept of the service or feature.

layout_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel1
layout_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: The most commonly used layout. This layout is the default layout that is used.

layout_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel2
layout_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: Used to display multiple sections in one screen. Contents grouped into sections are displayed, providing clarity on the categorization of information.

layout_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel3
layout_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: Used to display multiple sections in one screen. Contents grouped into sections are displayed, providing clarity on the categorization of information. A margin is inserted on both ends of the card to indicate that the card itself entails an action, compared to (2) Section. A 16px margin is inserted on the left and right side of the card.

layout_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel4
layout_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: Used when placing contents across the entire screen, such as a camera or promotion screen. The header area is rendered transparent so that the contents placed below is visible. Sufficient readability of the text in the header area must be ensured.

layout_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel5
layout_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: Used when displaying important information at the top of the screen. A color representing the service or feature intended as an “eye catcher” is specified for the top half of the screen. Refer to the flavor colors for the use of colors.

layout.layout_sect10_description: Below are the aspect ratios used for images and components placed in the screen. It is recommended to use these defined aspect ratios.

photo.title: Photo

principle_desc.desc: Photos are to enhance the brand image, help the user understand the contents without explaining it, and most importantly, show the user how to proceed with the next action.
Realistic images should always be used, not staged images. They should genuinely add value to PayPay.
It is most important to be informative, straightforward, and accessible.

size_desc.desc: Always prepare @3x images for better resolution.
Avoid oversized images in the app and always optimize them.

ratio_desc.desc: Avoid stretching or altering the original image aspect ratio.

dont_desc.desc: Motifs are not clear or out of focus
Do not Use photos owned by a third party without permission or that are watermarked.
Do not Show other brands or logos unless it is in the context.
Do not Use potentially offensive or sexual images.

photo.txt_dont_desc: Use photos taken in an environment or includes subjects that are unrelated.

dont_desc_1.desc: Use an image that causes a moiré effect.

principle_desc.desc: The shapes that comprise a component must be generic. Use of shapes that interfere with the readability of the information is prohibited.
Consistency is ensured by repeated use of shapes that follow the guideline, thereby fostering the PayPay brand.

title_usage_desc.desc: The corners of components are rounded to express a pleasant, friendly feeling.

shadow_sect1_description: Shadows are used to provide clarity on the layers within a screen.
A shadow indicates the priority of a given information or necessary action. It is recommended to use shadows effectively in areas that are to be highlighted.
shadow_sect2_description1: A screen consists of an overlap of multiple layers. Important information is displayed as top layers. Making this hierarchy visually evident provides clarity on the priority of contents, guiding the user to the necessary action.
The use of shadows with each layer makes it clear what layer is being displayed. Light sources/shadows including their direction and depth, etc. are kept consistent in the screen.
shadow.shadow_sect2_description2: The light source must always exist at a 90° degrees angle to the top. No other light sources are allowed.

shadow_sect2_images_tableholder2.name: panel1
shadow_sect2_images_tableholder2.desc: Correct light source (90° degrees orientation to the top)

shadow_sect2_images_tableholder2.name: panel2
shadow_sect2_images_tableholder2.desc: Incorrect light source (45° degrees orientation to the top)

shadow.shadow_sect2_description3:
A shadow is configured according to the layer in which it is placed.
According to the laws of physics, the lighter and larger the shadow becomes the further the distance becomes from the backmost layer.
shadow.shadow_sect3_description1: Used to highlight a particular piece of information or with a card UI that combines various information into one card.
shadow.shadow_sect3_description2: Used to indicate contents with a higher priority compared to contents placed in a low-shadow layer or to indicate an action component. A shadow is applied to this layer to make the information more recognizable when the contents in the lower, overlapping layer has a complex appearance, such as a map or graphic pattern. If the underlying layer of overlapping content is complex content (e.g., a map or a graphic), it should be shown at this level to make the information more recognizable.
shadow.shadow_sect3_description3: Used only for particularly high-priority information and actions. Prolific use of high-shadows within the same screen is prohibited.
shadow.shadow_sect3_description4: It is prohibited to specify a shadow with a different depth against a component that is placed on the same layer in the screen.

shadow_sect3_images_tableholder4.name: panel1
shadow_sect3_images_tableholder4.desc: The values used for the shadows are consistent.

shadow_sect3_images_tableholder4.name: panel2
shadow_sect3_images_tableholder4.desc: The values used for the shadows are inconsistent.

shadow.shadow_sect3_description5: This is the lowest level at which content is displayed. As a principle, it is recommended to use only the color white.
shadow.shadow_sect3_description6: No contents are displayed directly on this layer.
shadow.shadow_sect4_description: When placing text or an icon on top of a photo or complex contents, shadows are used to ensure the text or icon is sufficiently visible/readable.

shadow_sect4_images_tableholder.name: panel1
shadow_sect4_images_tableholder.desc: Displaying a button on top of a map.

shadow_sect4_images_tableholder.name: panel2
shadow_sect4_images_tableholder.desc: Displaying an action component when using the camera feature.

transition_sect1_description: It is mandatory to use a transition animation when it involves a screen transition as a result of the user’s action.
Displaying an animation provides clarity to the user on which screen is currently displayed.
transition_sect2_description1: When an action takes the user to a lower layer screen, a left to right animation is displayed to indicate a screen transition.
Similarly, when returning to a higher layer screen, a right to left animation is displayed.
transition.transition_sect2_description2: When displaying a temporary task that interrupts the current action, a screen is displayed by sliding it up from below.
transition.transition_sect2_description3: It is prohibited to use this screen transition when taking the user to a lower layer screen.

typography.title: Typography

principle_desc.desc: Only defined typography is used in the app. Specified font families are used to maintain consistency across all screens.
It is necessary to ensure readability/visibility, in a layout where the contents can be understood by anyone.
System fonts are used for Japanese text, and a custom font for English text. Unnecessary decorations and alternate custom fonts are not used
The PayPay app must support all languages. (Japanese and English is supported as of 2020)

title_usage_desc.desc: Only the font families defined below are used.

font_size_desc.desc: There are three font size definitions: heading, label and body.
All components consist of these three definitions.
Refer to the guideline for the fonts used for the different components.

heading_desc.desc: The size used for a header/title cannot be smaller than the size of a label/paragraph.

label_desc.desc: Used for sub-headers, action components, and supplementary information.
It is recommended to use bolded text for small sizes such as 9 or 10px.
Font sizes of 11px or below are not used for primary components.

body_txt_desc.desc: Used for information input by the user, articles, and descriptions of contents.
It is recommended to use 14px in principle. 16px must be used for important components.

line_height_desc.desc: This is the definition of line spacing.
The readability of text is ensured by maintaining sufficient line spacing.

typography.size_line_desc: Below is the line-up of the font sizes defined above.

text_color_desc.desc: This is the definition of text color by purpose.
Colors are selected from the color palette.
It is prohibited to use a particular color other than for the purpose it is defined for.

price_text_desc.desc: Given PayPay’s service, a price together with the yen mark is used heavily in the UI.
The price is one of the most critical pieces of information in a payment app and is therefore necessary to ensure sufficient readability.
The size of the text “yen” must be smaller than the price to ensure the price is easily viewable.

typography.text_desc: Below is the definition of the ratio between the price and the yen mark

typography_sect98_tableholder2.name: panel2
typography_sect98_tableholder2.col2: Use 1/2 of Number size as the 円 / Yen size
typography_sect98_tableholder2.col21: Example When the Price size is 72px, use 36px as the Yen size

typography_sect98_tableholder2.name: panel3
typography_sect98_tableholder2.col2: Use 12 px as the 円 / Yen size

typography_sect98_tableholder2.name: panel4
typography_sect98_tableholder2.col2: Use 11 px as the 円 / Yen size

balloon_sect1_description: A balloon is used to provide supplementary information about a particular component, such as a guide for a new feature.
Providing supplementary information that the user may otherwise have trouble finding out helps to facilitate a deeper understanding of the feature or component, resulting in a better experience.

A balloon is intended only to provide supplementary information. It should not be used in a way that interferes with users viewing the primary contents or making an action. A balloon is not used to promote a campaign.
balloon.balloon_sect3_description: There are two types of balloon components that are used depending on the purpose.

balloon_sect3_tableholder.name: no1
balloon_sect3_tableholder.balloon_sect3_col2: Used to highlight a particular component such as a new feature or guide the user to it.

balloon_sect3_tableholder.name: no2
balloon_sect3_tableholder.balloon_sect3_col2: Used to guide the user to a specific component that is not within the screen. Tapping the balloon will auto-scroll the user to the target component.

balloon_sect4_tableholder.name: no1
balloon_sect4_tableholder.balloon_sect4_col2: An icon matching the message or guide is displayed. Adding an icon helps to catch the user’s attention.

balloon_sect4_tableholder.name: no2
balloon_sect4_tableholder.balloon_sect4_col2: A promotional message or guiding text displayed in the balloon. It is recommended to keep the text concise and within one line so that the user can immediately understand its contents.

balloon_sect4_tableholder.name: no3
balloon_sect4_tableholder.balloon_sect4_col2: The arrow is placed so that it is positioned towards the component the balloon is intended for.
balloon_sect4_tableholder.balloon_sect4_col2_hints: Mouse hover on above image and scroll horizontally to view till end

balloon.balloon_sect5_description: Ensure that the subject matter is clear when using a coach balloon.
balloon.balloon_sect5_points1: It is clear which contents are intended to be highlighted.
balloon.balloon_sect5_points2: Place multiple balloons in the same screen. It is unclear which component is being highlighted.
balloon.balloon_sect5_points3: The balloon has poor visibility. It is placed on top of a background color close to that of the balloon.

balloon_sect6_tableholder.name: no1
balloon_sect6_tableholder.balloon_sect6_col2: A promotional message or guiding text displayed in the balloon. It is recommended to keep the text concise and within one line so that the user can immediately understand its contents.

balloon_sect6_tableholder.name: no2
balloon_sect6_tableholder.balloon_sect6_col2: An icon animation at the bottom of the screen which indicates that there is information outside of the screen.

balloon_sect6_description: There is a primary and secondary color used with scroll balloons.

The distinction is made according to the priority of the contents to be highlighted. It is recommended to use the secondary color to indicate new contents such as timeline notifications that are frequently updated, to avoid interfering with the contents that are displayed.

balloon_sect6_rowers.name: no1
balloon_sect6_rowers.balloon_sect6_subtitle: Used to promote a new feature off-screen, etc.

balloon_sect6_rowers.name: no2
balloon_sect6_rowers.balloon_sect6_subtitle: Used to display the number of new contents in a frequently updated timeline, etc.

balloon.balloon_sect7_description: It is prohibited to display a balloon in a way that interferes with viewing the primary contents in the screen or making an action.

balloon_sect7_tableholder.name: panel1
balloon_sect7_tableholder.balloon_sect7_col1: The text displayed is short and concise.

balloon_sect7_tableholder.name: panel2
balloon_sect7_tableholder.balloon_sect7_col1: The readability is low such as because it is broken up into two lines.

balloon_sect8_tableholder.name: panel1
balloon_sect8_tableholder.balloon_sect8_col2: Except in irregular cases, the balloon disappears once it or the component it is pointed towards is tapped. When promoting a component that does not require an action, the number of times the balloon is displayed is configured so that it disappears without the user having to take action. It is recommended to auto-hide the balloon after it is displayed three times.

balloon_sect8_tableholder.name: panel2
balloon_sect8_tableholder.balloon_sect8_col2:
The balloon disappears after it is tapped or when the user scrolls down/up. Tap feedback is displayed when action is taken. Refer to Specs for more information.
Reference：Interaction

balloon.balloon_sect11_title: Distance from the bottom of the screen

balloon_sect11_tableholder.name: panel1
balloon_sect11_tableholder.balloon_sect11_col1: When there is a bottom tab

balloon_sect11_tableholder.name: panel2
balloon_sect11_tableholder.balloon_sect11_col1: When there is no bottom tab

card_sect1_description: • Cards are used to organize, group and present complex information.
• Cards are an affordance for taps or swipe actions.
• A card UI should not be for decorative purposes only, but should be used to organize information or activating actions, and should do not be used for decorative purposes

card_sect3_tableholder.name: no1
card_sect3_tableholder.card_sect3_col2: When displaying content in a card, place sufficient margins around the content for readability. A card is an affordance for taps or swipe interactions, but the display of text links and icons are recommended to prompt actions more explicitly.

card_sect3_tableholder.name: no2
card_sect3_tableholder.card_sect3_col2: Shadow behind the card are displayed in accordance with the shadow guidelines providing for shadow elements such as layers, lighting, and shades.

card_sect4_tableholder.name: panel1
card_sect4_tableholder.card_sect4_col1: Display content outside the content area.

card_sect4_tableholder.name: panel2
card_sect4_tableholder.card_sect4_col1: Use different shadow styles for same layer cards.

card_sect5_tableholder.name: no1
card_sect5_tableholder.card_sect5_col2:
Displays tap feedback when activated.
See Specs for details.
Reference：Interaction

card_sect5_tableholder.name: no2
card_sect5_tableholder.card_sect5_col2: Tap feedback is not displayed when using the flip interaction of horizontally placed cards.

card.card_sect6_descriptions: Refer to Layout to check the value of the margins around and between cards.

form_sect1_description: • Forms are used for the user to enter free text.
• Clear instructions are provided to the user to specify the action that is required such as what should be entered and how many characters can be entered.
• The visual is changed according to the input status to allow the user to intuitively understand what the current status is, such as by not entered, entered and error.

form_sect2_images.name: panel1
form_sect2_images.desc: The height of the input area is fixed.

form_sect2_images.name: panel2
form_sect2_images.desc: The height of the input area is variable.

form.form_sect5_description:
Indicates the information that is to be input.
As a principle, the text must be concise so that the user can provide an appropriate response.
form.form_sect6_description:
This is the area where the user enters the required response.
The keyboard is displayed whenever the text field is selected.
Any additional information about the input or error, if any, is displayed in the message area.

form_sect7_tblholder.name: panel1
form_sect7_tblholder.form_sect7_col2_hint:
When the input area is empty, it is necessary to indicate what needs to be input.
The placeholder is used to indicate input examples or the title of the item to be input.
Any additional information about the input is displayed in the message area.

form_sect7_tblholder.name: panel2
form_sect7_tblholder.form_sect7_col2_hint:
The text that is entered by the user is displayed.
The input area is underlined by a bold blue line to indicate it is active.
A delete button is displayed as an action item when more than one character has been entered in the input area.

form_sect7_tblholder.name: panel3
form_sect7_tblholder.form_sect7_col2_hint: The input area is underlined by a blue line when the user has finished editing and the keyboard is out of focus.

form_sect7_tblholder.name: panel4
form_sect7_tblholder.form_sect7_col2_hint:
When the user inputs incorrect information, the input area is displayed in an error color to indicate that the input is incorrect.
At the same time, an error message is displayed in the message area to describe the reason of the error to the user.

form_sect7_tblholder.name: panel5
form_sect7_tblholder.form_sect7_col2_hint:
Indicates that no information can be input.
The line under the input error is greyed-out, indicating that it cannot be edited. Either a placeholder or value is displayed.

form.form_sect8_desc: Action items involving the information that is input.。

form_sect8_tblholder.name: panel1
form_sect8_tblholder.form_sect8_col2_hint:
The delete button must be displayed when a text consisting of one or more characters are displayed in the input area.
Tapping the button will delete the text that is entered.

form_sect8_tblholder.name: panel2
form_sect8_tblholder.form_sect8_col2_hint:
The visible/invisible option allows users to switch between invisible and visible states where the input is replaced by symbols.
This is used when entering sensitive information such as a password.
可視・The display of the icon is also switched so the user can recognize whether the current state is visible or invisible.
Users can also switch the icon display so that the visible and invisible states can be recognized. The invisible state is displayed by default.
In the invisible state, the text entered is replaced by “●” and displayed.

form.form_sect9_desc:
A text counter displays the number of characters typed and the maximum number of characters that can be entered.
It is updated on a real-time basis as the information is input.
When the character limit is reached, an error will be displayed in the message area

form_sect9_tblholder.hint: When the number of characters is within the limit.
When the number of characters exceeds the limit.

form_sect10_tblholder.hint:
Tap the text field when empty.
The keyboard is displayed and the text field will switch to the edit view. The animation used to display the keyboard must follow the device specifications.

The height of the input area is variable
When entering a long string of text, the text field will expand downward to fit the amount of text.

form_sect11_tblholder.form_sect11_col2:
Place holder
Label 16 Regular
Text Align-Left
#BABABA

Input
Label 16 Regular
Text Align-Left
#242323

header.header_sect1_desc:
• A header is the display of a screen title, action item or navigation item.
  • A header provides a clear and concise description of the content displayed on the screen or the purpose of the action to be taken.
  • A header provides clarity on the hierarchy of the screens displayed, enabling easy access to higher layers.
  • Headers are displayed in accordance with the specifications of the OS.

header_sect3_tblholder.name: panel1
header_sect3_tblholder.col2:
A header with a white background.
It is used for screens with little content such as a settings screen in which the actions available to the user are kept concise.

header_sect3_tblholder.name: panel2
header_sect3_tblholder.col2:
A header with transparent background.
The contents area can be extended to the header area. Any given color may be set as the background of the header.
It is used to create a content area with a spacious appearance, such as for primary features.

header.header_sect4_desc:
The background color is extended into the header area to enlarge and highlight the contents area as shown below, such as when displaying primary contents or campaign information
It is recommended to use a gradient background color.
header.header_sect5_hint: Headers are displayed in accordance with the specifications of the OS.
header.header_sect6_hint:
A navigation item is used to move between screens.
It clarifies the hierarchy of the screens displayed, enabling easy access to higher layers.

header_sect6_images.name: panel1
header_sect6_images.hint:
Back button
Displayed on screens displayed through a drill down.
Tapping it will take the user back to a higher layer screen.

header_sect6_images.name: panel2
header_sect6_images.hint:
Close button
A close button is displayed on the screens that are shown when slid up.
Tap to close the screen.

header.header_sect7_hint: A title contains the following information.
header.header_sect7_points:
• Screen name
• Feature name
• Action name
header.header_sect7_desc: Titles must follow the specifications of the device’s OS. The length of the text that is displayed varies on the width of the device. It is recommended to display a concise and compact title.
header.header_sect8_hint: Titles are concise and kept to within one line.

header_sect8_images.name: panel1
header_sect8_images.hint: The title is contained in one line.

header.header_sect9_1subdesc: A maximum of two action icons may be displayed. The icon(s) to be displayed must be of a feature related to the feature in the screen.
header.header_sect9_2subdesc:
Text buttons may be displayed.
The icon(s) to be displayed must be of a feature related to the feature in the screen.
In principle, it is recommended to use an icon button.
A text button is used only when it is difficult to express the feature just with an icon.

There must be sufficient space between the text button and the title text to ensure that the text is visible and readable.
The label text of the button should be short and concise. The use of two characters is recommended.
header.header_sect9_3subtitle: Save button for contents that are edited
header.header_sect9_3subdesc:
In an edit screen, a "save" button is displayed for the contents to be saved.
The display of the save button is alternated depending on the edit status.

header_sect9_3tblholder.name: panel1
header_sect9_3tblholder.col2: If any information is changed, the "save" button becomes activated, prompting the user to take action.

header_sect9_3tblholder.name: panel2
header_sect9_3tblholder.col2: If there is no change to the information, the "save" button is kept in an inactive state.

header.header_sect10_hint1: The header is fixed at the top of the screen when the user scrolls up/down.
header.header_sect10_hint2: Important contents that are displayed in the first view and that are desired to be displayed even after the user scrolls down can be displayed as a header.

header_sect12_tblholder.header_sect12_col2:
Regular
Heading16
Text Align-Center
#242323

Transparent
Heading16
Text Align-Center
#FFFFFF / #242323
Ensure enough contrast between the title text color and background color.
Use either one of the two colors above as the text color depending on the background color for the header.

24*24px/dp
Text- Active
Label 14 Bold
Text Align-Center
#3895FF

Text- non Active
Label 14 Bold
Text Align-Center
#BABABA

pagecontrols.pagecontrols_sect1_desc:
•Communicates to the user that there is more content available outside the screen, encouraging the user to flick through.
•It is important to accurately communicate the position of the content that is displayed when amongst various other content.
•Page controls are a supplementary component to provide a more convenient experience and should not interfere with the main content.
pagecontrols.pagecontrols_sect2_desc: The number of flickable banner images are displayed as a page control.

pagecontrols_sect3_images.name: panel1
pagecontrols_sect3_images.hint: The maximum number of contents recommended is 5.

pagecontrols_sect3_images.name: panel2
pagecontrols_sect3_images.hint: Interfering with the readability of text content is prohibited.

buttons.title: Buttons

usage_desc.desc: Actions are performed by tapping on the buttons.
The user should be made aware of the fact that the button is actionable, of the action it entails, its status and the interaction after it is tapped.
A button must be visually different from other contents in the screen, and should be placed so that it stands out.

type_desc.desc: There are several types of buttons that vary by the status or purposes.

buttons.subtitle_layout: Priority of buttons in a screen
buttons.txtlabel_desc1: The text in the text label is concise and immediately conveys what the action is to the user.
buttons.txtlabel_desc2: The use of a verb is recommended to clearly communicate the action.
buttons.background_desc1: Only predefined colors are used for buttons to maintain consistency of the roles and priorities of buttons within the app and to reduce the effort it takes the user to learn the UIUX.
buttons.background_desc2: A button with a white border and white text is accepted as an exception, only when placing it against a dark colored background such as black or on top of a photo.
buttons.icons_desc:
The icon can be included within the label to communicate the content of the button more visually.
It is recommended to use the color of the text for the icon as well.
An exception is a button with a white background, in which case, using a color for the icon that is different to the color of the text is allowed.
When using a given color for the icon, ensure that there is sufficient color difference and contrast between the color of the background and icon.

layout_desc.desc: Buttons are prioritized when there are multiple buttons in a screen. The type of button placed is determined based on the order of priority.
The priority should be straightforward to avoid users getting confused about what action they should take.

dont_desc.desc: It is prohibited to use buttons in such a way that the priority within the screen is unclear.

horizontal_button_desc.desc: When displaying information with equal priority or features, it is acceptable to place a maximum of two action buttons side by side.
When there are more than three options, either the buttons should be aligned vertically, or a different UI must be used.

buttons.horizontal_button_desc_1: It is recommended to use two different colors as the background color so the user can easily recognize the buttons as signifying different actions.
buttons.horizontal_button_desc_2: Refer to Color palette for the colors.
buttons.lauoyt_subtitle: The background color when using two buttons
buttons.lauoyt_subtitle_desc: Refer to Color palette for the colors

sticky_button_desc.desc: When placing an action button at the bottom of a long, vertical screen with a lot of content, it is recommended to use a sticky button, which is fixed at the bottom of the screen, so the button is available in the first view.
The button is placed on the higher layer of the contents that is displayed. Ensure there is enough space surrounding the button.
The area outside of the sticky button is the area subject to scrolling.

keyboard_button_desc.desc: In a screen in which the user is required to enter information, the display of the button is fixed above the keyboard.
Sufficient space is provided around the button (above, below, left and right) to avoid accidental taps on adjacent contents or the keyboard.

detail_dont.desc: The text must be short and concise, immediately conveying what the action is.
It is prohibited to allow the button text to break up into two lines.

interaction_desc.desc: Tap feedback is displayed when an action is taken.

buttons_design_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel4
buttons_design_sect3_images_tableholder.buttons_design_sect3_images_colo2: Used for actions that would cause the user to suffer a loss if used incorrectly, such as the deleting of user data.

buttons_design_sect3_images_tableholder.name: panel5
buttons_design_sect3_images_tableholder.buttons_design_sect3_images_colo2: Used when the action is disabled.

dont_img_desc.desc: The priority of the options is clear
The priority of the options is unclear

buttons_sect97_tableholder.name: panel1
buttons_sect97_tableholder.col2: It is recommended to use two different colors as the background color so the user can easily recognize the buttons as signifying different actions. It is not mandatory to use PayPay’s Primary Blue color.

buttons_sect97_tableholder.name: panel2
buttons_sect97_tableholder.col2: It is recommended to display an icon so that people can easily recognize that the two buttons are for different actions.

dont_details.desc_1: The action is clear & short. The text fits into one line.
The text is long and the action unclear.
dont_details.desc_2: The text is broken up into two lines.

dont_details_3.desc: The visibility of the icon is ensured.
The visibility of the icon is bad.
The priority of the information becomes unclear by using an icon.
The status of the button and the icon does not make sense.

sticky_button_table.name: panel2
sticky_button_table.col2:
Add a shadow to the top part of the background
Shadow : -90° Low-Shadow

expand.title: Expand

usage_desc.desc: An expander is used to collapse contents containing a lot of information.
Information can be better organized by placing it within an expander, improving the readability of the content following below.
An expander is used only for secondary or supplementary information, not for any primary contents
Information that is collapsed is expanded-out by tapping on it.
The information can be collapsed back to its previous state by tapping it again.

expand.usage_example_desc: The expander is used to collapse supplementary contents containing a lot of information.

type_desc.desc: There are three types of expand components that are used according to the purpose.

card_desc.desc: Cards are used to group contents containing a lot of information.

list_desc.desc: A list is used when there are many items to show, to secure browsability.
A list can only be used for contents that can be categorized into categories and subcategories.

article_desc.desc: Used to collapse long text contents such as articles.
Placing information within an expander improves the readability of the contents and action components following below.

interaction_desc.desc: The collapsed/expanded UI is alternated by tapping on the expander.
Tap feedback is displayed upon tapping.

expand.interaction_desc_3: Animations are applied to the content that is expanded and the arrow icon to make it easier for the user to recognize the changed state.

expand_details_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel1
expand_details_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: A downward arrow icon is displayed to indicate that it will expand when tapped on. It is recommended that the default view is in a collapsed state. A text label is displayed to make it easy for the user to guess what information will be displayed after expanding it.

expand_details_sect9_images_tableholder.name: panel2
expand_details_sect9_images_tableholder.desc: An upward arrow icon is displayed to indicate that the information can be collapsed again.

expand_list_details_tableholder.name: panel1
expand_list_details_tableholder.desc:
The highest tier items are displayed.
A downward arrow icon is displayed to indicate that it will expand when tapped on.
It is possible that the user may miss the expand action in a list.
In the default display, it is recommended to display only one high tier category in a collapsed state.
The action that can be taken becomes unclear to the user if the subcategories after collapsing does not fit into the first view, which is why the collapsed UI is used as the default display.

expand_list_details_tableholder.name: panel2
expand_list_details_tableholder.desc:
The lower tier items are displayed.
An upward arrow icon is displayed to indicate that the information can be collapsed again.

expand_article_details_tableholder.name: panel1
expand_article_details_tableholder.desc:
A text label is displayed such as "read more" to indicate that it will expand when tapped on.
A color that is weaker compared to the color of the body text is used avoid confusion.
The last line of the body text is omitted by using an ellipsis (“…”).
The exact position of the omission depends on the width of the device.

expand_article_details_tableholder.name: panel2
expand_article_details_tableholder.desc:
Displays all the contents that had been collapsed.
No action is provided to restore to the collapsed state
It can be restored to the collapsed state by reloading the page.

expand_spec_card_tableholder.name: panel1
expand_spec_card_tableholder.desc:
Heading / Label 14
Text Align-Center
Default : #00B9F5
Pressed( iOS ) : #00B9F5, Alpha 0.7

halfsheets.title: Half Sheets

usage_desc.desc: Half sheets are used to temporarily interrupt the user to facilitate a particular action or to display a notification such as an error.
A half sheet is used only to display secondary information. It is not recommended to display primary contents in a half sheet (with the exception of mini apps).
The reason for the half sheet being displayed and the next action required by the user is clearly displayed on the half sheet.

halfsheets.interaction_desc: Tap feedback is displayed after the button is tapped.
halfsheets.txt_button_desc: When multiple buttons are displayed, ensure they are prioritized so that there is no confusion for the user on what to do next.

halfsheet_sect3_images_colo2.desc: An image is placed to clearly convey the subject matter displayed in the half sheet.
Error Icon
When displaying an error or alert, a common error icon or feature-specific error icon is displayed.
Refer to iconography for details.
The title is displayed.
A single sentence that is single and concise is used as a title to provide a direct understanding of the contents.
A full stop is not used to punctuate the title.
Supplementary information that could not be fit into the title is displayed.
A full stop is not used to punctuate the description.
Link text is displayed.
In many cases, it is a link to the help page or to the terms and conditions to obtain the user’s consent, etc.
It is prohibited to use as a primary action button, and is only used as a supplementary component.
It is recommended to display up to three links only.
The display patterns are described later on
An action button is displayed.
It is possible to display between one to three buttons.
When multiple buttons are displayed, ensure they are prioritized so that there is no confusion for the user on what to do next.
The display patterns of buttons are described later on.
This is the background of the half sheet.
The height varies depending on the subject matter of the contents displayed.
When displaying a half sheet, a black transparent background is applied as an overlay so that the contents beneath can be recognized.
In principle, the half sheet is closed if this area is tapped.
In the following cases, the half sheet does not close even when said area is tapped.
•  If an inconsistency occurs in the behavior or contents displayed due to the half sheet being closed without the action it entails getting completed.
•  If the same result occurs such as an error, even after closing the half sheet and attempting the same action again.

halfsheets_integration_data.desc: Tap feedback is displayed after the button is tapped.
Buttons Refer it for more details

label.title: Label

usage_desc.desc: Labels are used to provide clarity on information supplementary to the contents or its status.
When displaying multiple statuses in the screen, they are color-coded so that the difference is visually apparent.

label.do_dont_desc: It is recommended not to include an action item in the label.。
label.desc_statuslabel: A status label is used to indicate different statuses when more than one status exists in the contents.。
label.newlabel_desc1: A new label is used to promote a feature to the user such as a new feature.
label.newlabel_desc2: The text and color cannot be changed.
label.newlabel_desc3: The label should disappear after the item is tapped one to three times to avoid attracting unnecessary attention. (One tap is recommended)

label_data2.desc: It is recommended not to include an action item in the label.
It is prohibited to use more than two lines in a label.

label_data3.desc: It is prohibited to display multiple new labels in one screen.

label_data4.desc1: It is recommended to use colors from theColor palettewhen representing a status.
label_data4.desc2: Refer to the functional color palette in particular when representing statuses such as “done” or “error”.

sect1_desc.desc: Toast is used to provide feedback to the user on the result of the action they took.
By receiving the feedback, the user will come to know of whether their action was successful or not.
The contents conveyed in the toast must be simple and clear.

toast.sect3_desc1: Toast is used to inform the user of the result of the action they took.
toast.sect3_desc2: It must be automatically deleted after the feedback on the result is given to avoid interfering with other contents

toast_data1.desc: It is prohibited to add action items.
It is prohibited to display two or more lines of text.

toast_data2.desc: A background color is displayed outside of the safe area as well for devices that have a safe area.

sect1_desc.desc: Tabs are used to display varying groups of information containing a lot of information in one screen.
A summary of these information groups is displayed in the first view. The user can switch between the information groups by tapping the tab.

tab.sect5_title: When it doesn’t fit into the first view
tab.sect5_desc1: When there are many tabs and it is difficult to display all of them in the first view, some tabs can be displayed off-screen.
tab.sect5_desc3: When using this UI, there is a risk that many users will not notice that they can swipe across.
tab.sect5_desc4: Ensure that the user intuitively understands that the tabs continue off-screen, such as by displaying only part of the tab on the far right.
tab.sect6_desc1: The tabs are fixed at the top of the screen when scrolling, so that the user can check the status of the tab at any given time and switch tabs if necessary.

tab_data1_colo2.desc: This is the standard tab navigation. The contents that are displayed below the tab can be switched by switching tabs.
This is a tab navigation which slides within the screen. By switching the tab, it automatically scrolls to a specific position within the contents in the same screen.

The scrolling action is linked with the tabs. Therefore, scrolling within the screen to a particular part of the contents makes the tab related to the contents displayed active, even if the tab was not actively switched.

tab_data2_colo2.desc: This is the state of a tab when it is selected.
It is recommended to have the tab on the far left selected by default when the screen is displayed.
PayPay Blue is recommended as the color to indicate the selected state, but it may be changed to another color to suit the service color.
When changing the color, there must be enough contrast between the background and the color of the text.
This is the state of a tab when it is not selected.
Tapping the tab will change it to a selected state. The related contents are displayed below the tab.

tab_data3_colo2.desc: This is the state of a tab when it is selected.
It is recommended to have the tab on the far left selected by default when the screen is displayed.
PayPay Blue is recommended as the color to indicate the selected state, but it may be changed to another color to suit the service color.
When changing the color, there must be enough contrast between the background and the color of the text.
This is the state of a tab when it is not selected.
Tapping the tab will change it to a selected state. At the same time, the contents displayed will automatically scroll to the position of the contents in the same screen.

sect1_desc.desc: Selection controls are used when selecting an item.
Items must be displayed in a way in that their role and current state can be recognized instantly.
Selection controls are not used for single items, and should always be accompanied by text indicating what options there are.

selectionControls.sect6_desc1: An icon can be added within the select button.
selectionControls.sect6_desc2: When unselected, the icon should be colored. When selected it should be white.
selectionControls.sect7_desc1: An icon can be added within the select button.
selectionControls.sect7_desc2: When unselected, the icon should be colored. When selected it should be white.

selectnControlData1_colo2.desc: Used when only one option can be selected.
The user can select only one option.
When an alternative item is selected, the item previously selected changes to a state of being unselected.
Used when multiple options can be selected.
Unlike the radio button, the user can select multiple options at once.
By selecting an item that is already selected, the item changes to a state of being unselected.
Can be used in both cases; one option only and multiple options.
The select button is used to emphasize the available options when listing them horizontally.
This type is recommended as a selection UI within the app.
Used when turning an item ON/OFF.

selectnControlData2.name: panel4
selectnControlData2.col1: 編集不可・選択時 / Disabled - Selected

selectnControlData3.name: panel4
selectnControlData3.col1: 編集不可・選択時 / Disabled - Selected

selectnControlData6.desc: Use the radio button when multiple items can be selected.
Use the check box when only one item can be selected.

sect1_desc.desc: A loop animation is displayed when loading to inform the user that it is being processed.
The placement of an animation reduces the perceived wait time providing the user with a smoother feeling.

loadingAnimation.sect2_desc2: In principle, this is the animation that is used.
loadingAnimation.sect3_desc1: The OS’s default pull to refresh component is used when manually refreshing the contents in the screen.
loadingAnimation.sect5_desc1: In accordance with the OS’s guideline.

list.list_sect1_desc:
•Lists are used to organize a variety of information and ensure high browsability.
•A list must comprise a particular sequence to ensure the user can immediately understand and compare its contents.
•Text and icons are used to concisely communicate the content of the list or evoke what interaction will follow after the user makes an action.
•The style of a list is different according to whether it is in iOS or Android.

list_sect4_col2.content: A list header is used to add an overall title when grouping multiple lists.
A sub list header is used to add a title to subcategories that fall under a
redicon1.svg
list header. A
redicon1.svg
list header must always be used for the higher level. A
redicon2.svg
A sub list header may not be used as a high level category.
An icon is displayed when visually expressing the subject matter of the text.
A short and concise display of the contents.
It is recommended to keep the text within one line.
A description is a display of text supplementing the title. Like
redicon4.svg
, it is kept short and concise.
It is recommended to keep the text within one line.
An action item can be the status of particular contents or an actionable item, and is placed on a right alignment.
If the action item consists of text, it is recommended to keep the text within 5 characters.
There should be sufficient space between an action item and a title or description.
For iOS or web, an arrow icon must be added to a list in which the user can tap and access a lower level screen.
This icon is not required for Android.

list.list_sect7_desc:
The collapsed/expanded UI is alternated by tapping on the expander.
Tap feedback is displayed when the list is tapped.
Refer to the specs.
list.list_sect8_desc:
When using a list header, it is fixed immediately below the header when the user scrolls up/down the screen
Fixing its position provides clarity on the list items that are displayed even when scrolling.
list.list_sect9_desc: The display of particular parts comprising a list varies according to the OS.

list_sect9_tblholder.name: panel2
list_sect9_tblholder.col2: An arrow icon must be added to a list in which the user can tap and access a lower level screen.
list_sect9_tblholder.col3: An arrow icon is not displayed regardless of any screen transition.

list_sect9_tblholder.name: panel3
list_sect9_tblholder.col2: A 16px margin is maintained to the left of the border.
list_sect9_tblholder.col3: No margin is maintained next to the border.

list_sect12_tblholder.name: panel1
list_sect12_tblholder.col2:
24*24px/dp
Refer to Iconography for the icon specs.
When using an icon, it is horizontally centered even when the title consists of multiple lines.

slider.slider_sect1_desc:
•A slider allows selecting a fixed value from within a range of selectable values between a minimum and maximum or selecting a range of values.
•Since the range of selectable values is visualized as well as the state of what is selected, it facilitates easy awareness of the relativity between values.
•A slider allows for a more intuitive touch compared to entering a value using the keyboard or a tap count button.
slider.slider_sect2_desc: Sliders may be used for volume control or selecting a price range.
slider.slider_sect3_desc:
A relative slider is used when it is difficult to enter a specific value, such as volume control.
An icon is placed at either end of the bar, allowing the user to specify any point in between.
slider.slider_sect4_desc:
A range slider is used to select a range of values between two specific values.
The minimum and maximum values are displayed on both ends. The user can select a range of values by specifying two values along the bar.
slider.slider_sect5_desc:
A scale slider is used when making a predetermined value an option, such selecting a size.
Selectable options are placed on either end or along the bar. The options are accompanied with text. The user can only select an option.
The use cannot select any other point along the bar.

slider_sect6_tblholder.name: panel1
slider_sect6_tblholder.col2:
Indicates the range selected by the user.
The values between the minimum value and selected value are displayed in an active color to facilitate awareness of the relativity with values within the bar.

slider_sect6_tblholder.name: panel2
slider_sect6_tblholder.col2: Indicates the unselected values along the bar.

slider_sect6_tblholder.name: panel3
slider_sect6_tblholder.col2:
The point that can be controlled by dragging.
It indicates an action at the same time as a selected state.

slider_sect6_tblholder.name: panel4
slider_sect6_tblholder.col2:
Icons representing the role of the slider.
The minimum and maximum designs must be differentiated to provide intuitive clarity on the role and status of each.

slider_sect7_tblholder.name: panel1
slider_sect7_tblholder.col2:
Indicates the range selected by the user.
The selected range is displayed in an active color to facilitate awareness of the relativity with values within the bar.

slider_sect7_tblholder.name: panel2
slider_sect7_tblholder.col2: Indicates the unselected values along the bar.

slider_sect7_tblholder.name: panel3
slider_sect7_tblholder.col2:
The point that can be controlled by dragging.
It indicates an action at the same time as a selected state.

slider_sect7_tblholder.name: panel4
slider_sect7_tblholder.col2: In text, the minimum value is displayed on the left end and the maximum value on the right end.

slider_sect7_tblholder.name: panel5
slider_sect7_tblholder.col2:
The minimum and maximum values of the selected range are displayed as text.
Although displaying this is optional, it does add convenience for the user.
Refer to Interaction for further details on the behavior.

slider_sect8_tblholder.name: panel1
slider_sect8_tblholder.col2:
A preview of the value.
Although displaying this is optional, it does allow the user an intuitive decision on which value to select.
When selected, the sample value changes to an active state as well.

slider_sect8_tblholder.name: panel2
slider_sect8_tblholder.col2:
The option that is not selected.
When using a scale slider, only inactive points can be selected.
By tapping on the bar, whichever inactive point that is closest will be selected.

slider_sect8_tblholder.name: panel3
slider_sect8_tblholder.col2: Indicates the state of a value that is selected.

slider_sect8_tblholder.name: panel4
slider_sect8_tblholder.col2:
Displays the selectable values as text.
The text is short and concise.
It is recommended to keep the text within 2 to 4 characters.

slider.slider_sect9_desc:
An animation is used to clearly communicate any change to a given state.
It is recommended to use Haptiv Feedback for iOS to provide intuitive feedback on the fact that a value has been selected.

slider_sect9_images.name: panel1
slider_sect9_images.hint:
The active point moves when selected
The active point will slide to the point corresponding to the selected value.
*A GIF is used

slider_sect9_images.name: panel2
slider_sect9_images.hint:
The input value balloon expands when selected
The input value balloon of the active point being handled is enlarged.
By enlarging it, the value being handled is given better clarity.
The balloon returns to its original size once the user finishes selecting a value and lets go of the active point.
*A GIF is used

slider.slider_sect10_desc:
It is recommended to add feedback when the user selects a value to provide clarity on the status of the option selected.
See below examples of feedback.

slider_sect10_images.name: panel1
slider_sect10_images.hint:
Volume Settings
Enable the user to check the selected volume by triggering a test sound.

slider_sect10_images.name: panel2
slider_sect10_images.hint:
Font Size Settings
Display a sample UI below the slider and enable the user to check the selected size by updating
the font size according to the value selected in the slider.

slider_sect11_tblholder.name: panel3
slider_sect11_tblholder.col2:
12*12px/dp
Ensure a tap area of at least 35*35.

slider_sect12_tblholder.name: panel2
slider_sect12_tblholder.col2:
12*12px/dp
Ensure a tap area of at least 35*35.

slider_sect12_tblholder.name: panel4
slider_sect12_tblholder.col2:
Back ground
#FFFFFF
Shadow: Low Shadow

Numbers
Label 16 Body
Text Align-Center

Text Align-Center
#3895FF

Text Align-Center
#3895FF

Units (Kanji characters)

Text Align-Center
#3895FF

slider_sect13_tblholder.name: panel1
slider_sect13_tblholder.col2:
Default
Label 14 Regular
Text Align-Center
#606060

Selected
Label 14 Bold
Text Align-Center
#3895FF
The text size can be changed depending on the purpose.

slider_sect13_tblholder.name: panel3
slider_sect13_tblholder.col2:
Default
12*12px/dp
Ensure a tap area of at least 35*35.
Selected
20*20px/dp
Ensure a tap area of at least 35*35.
